_header: Lordings there is in Yorkshire as I guess
_description: Geoffrey Chaucer, the Summoner’s Tale of the Canterbury Tales — 586 lines in rhyming couplets.

BodArcSelB14.First Lines:
Lordynges there is in yorke shire as I gessea merssh contre called
                    holdernesse…
BodArcSelB14.Last Lines:
…and Iankyn hath I wonne a newe gownemy tale is don we ben
                    almoste at towne
BodArcSelB14.Note:
III.1731, 1873-4, 2229 omitted; spurious lines follow 1732, 2230; 2101-2
                    reversed; 1937, 1938, 1941 partially blank.
BodArcSelB14.Attributed Title:
…And / next folwith his tale to angre the ffrere (f.
                    106v); the sompnour (RT); Here endith the Sompnour is tale… (f.
                        114v)

BodBar20.First Lines:
Lordynges þer is in Yorkeshire as I gesseA merschy Contre
                    called holdernesse…
BodBar20.Last Lines:
…And Iankyn hath I wonne a new gowneMyn tale is don we ben
                    almost at towne
BodBar20.Note:
III.1731, 1750, 1873-4 omitted; 2101-2 reversed; 1768 inserted in
                    margin.
BodBar20.Attributed Title: here begynne þe sompnoures tale (f. 126); Sompnour (RT)

Bod414.First Lines:
[L]Ordingis ther is in yorkshire as I gesseA marshe cuntre callid
                    holdirnesse…
Bod414.Last Lines:
…And Iankyn hath wonne a new gounMy tale is done we ben almost
                    at the toun

Bod686.First Lines:
Lordings þer is in yorkeshire as y gesseA mershcontre called
                    holdernesse…
Bod686.Last Lines:
…And Iankin hath ywonne a new gowneMy tale is don we ben
                    almost at toune
Bod686.Attributed Title:
…And begynneþ his tale (f. 91v); Somnour (RT); Here
                    endeth þe Somnours tale… (f. 98v)

BodHatDon1.First Lines:
Lordinges þere is in yorkshire as I gesseA Merssh contre
                    called holdernesse…
BodHatDon1.Last Lines:
…And Iankyn hath wonnen a newe gownMi tale is don we be al
                    most atte town
BodHatDon1.Attributed Title:
…And next / biginneth the Somnours tale (f. 129); The Somnours tale
                    (RT); Here endeth þe tale of the Somnour… (f.
                    135v)

BodLauMis600.First Lines:
…In euery hous he gan to poore and prieAnd beggeþ mele
                    chese or elles corn…
BodLauMis600.Last Lines:
…And Ienkyn haþ wone a newe gowneMi tale is don we be
                    almost at towne
BodLauMis600.Note:
III.1709-37 lost (resupplied on leaves added in the seventeenth century,
                    ff. 100-1); 1805, 1873-4 2229 omitted; 1805 inserted lated; spurious line
                    follows 2230; 1747-8, 2101-2 reversed.

BodLauMis739.First Lines:
[L]ordyngs ther is in yorkshire as I gesseA merssh countre y callid
                    holdernesse…
BodLauMis739.Last Lines:
…And forth he goth with a wele angry chereHe ne had noȝt
                    ellis for his sermoneTo parte among his bretherin whan he come homeAnd
                    thus this tale is I donffor we were almost at þe toune
BodLauMis739.Note:
III.1748, 1764, 2144, 2159-2294 omitted; four spurious lines follow
                    2158.

BodRawPoe141.First Lines:
LOrdynges ther is in ȝork shyre as I gesseA merssh contre
                    cleped holdernesse…
BodRawPoe141.Last Lines:
…And commandyng hem thei shulde before hym stondAnd sodenly he
                    toke his bowe on his hond…
BodRawPoe141.Attributed Title: Here bigynneth the sompnors tale (f. 148); The sompnor (RT)

BodRawPoe149.First Lines:
Lordynges ther is in yorkeshire as I gesseA marsh cuntre called
                    holdernes…
BodRawPoe149.Last Lines:
…And forth he goth with a ful angri chereHe ne had noght elles
                    for his sermonto departe amonge his brethren when he come homeAnd thus
                    is this tale y doneFor we were almoost atte toune

BodRawPoe223.Last Lines:

                    almost at towne
BodRawPoe223.Attributed Title:

                        ffratre (RT); Here endith the sompnors tale… (f.
                    157v)

CULDd424.First Lines:
Lordyngges there is in ȝorkshire as I gesseA mersshy contre
                    called holdernesse…
CULDd424.Last Lines:
…And Iankyn hath I wonne a newe GovneMy Tale is doon we ben
                    almost at Tovn quod Wytton

CULGg427.First Lines:
…A godis kechil or a trip of cheseOr ellis what ȝow
                    lyste we may not chese…
CULGg427.Last Lines:
…That I may vouche saf I sey for meHe hadde þe ferste
                    smel of fartys thre…

Parkes,  Malcolm B.,  and  Richard Beadle.

CULIi326.First Lines:
LOrdynges quod he there is in yorkeshyre as I gesseA mercche contre
                    that called is holdernesse…
CULIi326.Last Lines:
…And Ienkyn hath y wonne a newe gownMy tale is done we be
                    almoste at the town
CULIi326.Note:
III.2229 omitted; 1963-4 reversed; spurious lines follow 1745,
                    2230.
CULIi326.Attributed Title:
…And here begynneth his tale (f. 129); Sompnour (RT); Here Endeth the
                    Sompnours tale… (f. 135)

CULMm25.First Lines:
Lordynges þer is in ȝorkeschire as I gesseA mersshy
                    countre called holdernesse…
CULMm25.Last Lines:
…Beforne þis day of suche a questiounWho schulde make a
                    demonstraconHe ne had not ells for his sermounTo parte amonge his
                    brethern when he come homeAnd þus is þis tale ydoneffor we
                    were almoste at þe toun
CULMm25.Note:
III.1726, 1731, 1873-4, 2225-94 omitted; 2101-2 reversed; spurious lines
                    follow 1732, 2224.
CULMm25.Attributed Title:
Here begynneth þe somnours tale (f. 133); þe somnere (RT); Here
                    endith þe somnours tale… (f. 139)

CamFitzMc181.First Lines:
[L]Ordynges þer is in yorke schyre as y gesseA mersche cuntre
                    called holdenesse…
CamFitzMc181.Last Lines:
…Come lepynge in and chased oute þe ffrereAnd forth he
                    goth with a full angry chereHe ne had nouȝte ell for his
                    sermouneTo departe amonge his breddrn when he come homeAnd þus ys
                    the tale of the frere ydonffor we were almost at þe toun
CamFitzMc181.Note:
III.1731, 1748, 1887-8, 1991-8, 2005-10, 2051-2, 2079-85, 2101, 2111-12,
                    2115-20, 2159-2294 omitted; spurious lines follow 1732, 2086, 2158. The rest of
                    the verso and the following recto and verso are left blank following the
                        Tale.
CamFitzMc181.Attributed Title:
The tale of þe Sompnoure (f. 152v, rubric); Sompnoure (RT);
                    Her endeth the Sompnours Tale (f. 158v, rubric)

CamTCC582.First Lines:
…Had prechid at a chirche in his manereAnd specialli abouen
                    eueri thing…
CamTCC582.Last Lines:
…And Iankyn hath I wonne a newe gouneMy tale is don we ben
                    almost at towne
CamTCC582.Attributed Title: Hiere endith the tale of the Sompnour… (f. 66rb)

                    at toune

CamTCC595.Attributed Title:

                    þat is our lifes leche…
BLAdd25718.Last Lines:

                    moste at toune

                    forthe he goth with a fulle angry chereNe ne hade nouȝt elles for hys

                    þis tal ydonffor we were almoste at þe town

Austin143.First Lines:
Lordynges there is in yorke Shire as y gesseA Mershe Contre Callid
                    holdernesse…
Austin143.Last Lines:
…And Iankyn hath wonne a newe gowneMy tale is done we be all
                    moste at Towne
Austin143.Note:

                    reversed.
Austin143.Attributed Title:
…Et incipit fabula eiusdem (f. 85v); Sompnoure
                    (RT); Hic finitur fabula Sompnitoris… (f.92)

Lordynges ther ys in ȝork schyre as y gesseA mershy contre
                    called holdernesse…
PhilRos10841.Last Lines:
…And forth he gooth with a full angry chereHe ne had not elles
                    for hys sermonTo parte amonge hys bretheren when he come homAnd this
                    ys the tale ydonffor we were almoste at þe town

…and begynneth þe tale (f. 100); The Tale (RT); The somnor (Rt);
                    Here endeth þe sompnours tale… (f. 106)

                    callid is holdirnes…

                    at town

BNangl39.First Lines:
Lordyngis ther is in yorkshire as I gessea mery cuntre callid
                    holdirnesse…
BNangl39.Last Lines:
…he nys no foole ne no domyakand Iankyn hath I wonne a newe
                    gounmy tale is doon and wee be almost at toun
BNangl39.Attributed Title:
…& subsequenter incipit fa / bule eiusdem hoc modo
                        sequente (f. 47ra); Explicit fabula apparitoris…
                    (f. 50rb)

TokyoTak22.First Lines:
Lordyngis þer is in ȝorkschire as I gessea merssh contre
                    callyd holdernsse…
TokyoTak22.Last Lines:
…and Iohnkyn hath I wonne a newe gownemy tale is done and we
                    be nygh at towne
TokyoTak22.Note:
III.1907-11, 2229 omitted; spurious lines follow 2230, 2232. Following
                        Summoner’s Tale, at the foot of f. 77v, the scribe
                    copies the opening line of Clerk’s Prologue—‘Syr clerk
                    of Oxinford oure ost seyde’—before realizing he has already copied
                    that text (4860). He
                    then adds ‘vt supra’, and below that ‘Vtile con
                        cilium dominus ne despice serui’.

                        98v)
